head.title: Arrest Made a Week Later at Murder Scene

hedline.hl1: Arrest Made a Week Later at Murder Scene

block.p: A man was charged with murder yesterday after detectives saw him in the subway station where a man was murdered a week ago and thought he fit the description of the suspect, a transit police spokesman said.
"He literally returned to the scene of the crime one week later," said the spokesman, Al O'Leary.

A man was charged with murder yesterday after detectives saw him in the subway station where a man was murdered a week ago and thought he fit the description of the suspect, a transit police spokesman said.
"He literally returned to the scene of the crime one week later," said the spokesman, Al O'Leary.
The suspect, Steven Jenkins, 27 years old, of 300 Lexington Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, was charged with second-degree murder and first-degree robbery, Mr. O'Leary said.
Mr. Jenkins was spotted in the 63d Drive subway station in Rego Park, Queens, at 4:30 A.M. Saturday by members of a task force of detectives from the transit and city police, he said.
The detectives were canvassing the area where 53-year-old Walter Heitlinger was shot to death during a robbery on May 25, Mr. O'Leary said.
They questioned Mr. Jenkins based on similarities between the suspect and a composite sketch that was put together based on eyewitness accounts, he said.
Mr. Jenkins was formally charged yesterday after witnesses to the murder positively identified him, Mr. O'Leary said.
